Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement Grant: Morphosyntactic Development in a Second Language: An eye tracking study of the role of attention

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Understanding the factors that influence language acquisition--not only in the case of a learner's first (or native) language, but also in the case of second language acquisition--is an important goal of research on human language and communication.

Learning a second language is arguably one of the most complex learning tasks for the adult mind and results in great variability in attainment of the second language, particularly for grammar. One cognitive factor that may account for this variability is attention. It has been widely assumed, under both theoretical and applied perspectives on second language learning, that attention to grammatical forms leads to acquisition of those forms. However, there is scant direct empirical evidence to support this claim in the field. In contrast, research in the field of cognitive science has produced ample evidence that suggests that attention is crucial for various types of cognitive operations, including learning. Thus, our understanding of attention in second language learning may be further elucidated by adopting theoretical perspectives, such as the distinction between external attention (cued by properties of the object itself) and internal attention (cued by task manipulations related to the object), and by the use of experimental methods from cognitive science, such as eye tracking, to examine this distinction.

Under the direction of Dr. Kara Short, Bernard Issa's dissertation project implements such an innovative approach to address the following questions: (i) Does increased attention to particular second language grammatical forms lead to increased learning of those forms? (ii) Are there differential effects of external and internal attention on second language learning? To answer these questions, the eye-movements of novice learners of Spanish will be recorded as an index of attention while learning a new grammatical form under either external or internal manipulations of attention.

The results from this interdisciplinary project are expected to provide novel, direct evidence for the role of attention in second language learning, lead to a greater understanding of attention in learning more generally, and have direct implications for pedagogy. Finally, this project will further opportunities for involvement, training, and interdisciplinary collaborations in research for a graduate student and for undergraduate researcher assistants, who are likely to come from underrepresented groups in cognitive science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit. The findings of this project have advanced the field’s understanding of the role of attention in adult second language learning by employing a real-time concurrent measures of participant eye-movements as a measurement of attention while learning morphosyntactic forms. The project has provided direct, empirical evidence that attention is curcial for second language learning. Furthermore, by recording participant eye-movements under two attentional conditions (external versus internal attention) this project has provided novel, fine-grained insights into the mechanisms of attention that operate during second language learning and how these mechanisms correspond to eye-movement data. This project’s interdisciplinary focus has merged theories and methods from cognitive science with second language learning and linguistics to provide informative results for researchers in both fields. Namely, regarding cognitive science, these results add to the literature related to visual attentional allocation and extend them to incorporate natural language as the target of attention. Moreover, the results contribute novel direct evidence to the line of research dedicated to instructed second language acquisition (i.e., research that investigates the effectiveness of instructional techniques), by providing evidence in support of both of the two instructional interventions employed in this project (Input Enhancement and Structured Input practice).

Broader impact. By lending empirical support to the use of instructional interventions that manipulate external attention, or internal attention, this project may directly impact the way in which second language instructional materials are created in the future and therefore influence the way in which second languages are taught at the K-12 and university levels. Furthermore, given that the University of Illinois at Chicago (UIC) has a diverse student body, this project recruited participants from a various diverse background which resulted in the inclusion of underrepresented groups in research. In addition, the completion of the project has allowed Co-PI’s to expand their research repertoire to include the use of eye-tracking as a powerful, online technique for examining language processing. The inclusion of eye-tracking as a methodological tool in this project has fostered collaborations at UIC (a public research university) between multiple departments—i.e., the Departments of Psychology, Linguistics and Hispanic and Italian Studies. Furthermore, through past and future presentations at professional conferences (past: The European Second Language Association in September 2014, The Hispanic Linguistics Symposium in November 2014; upcoming: The Second Language Research Forum in October 2015 and the Psychonomics Society Annual Meeting in November 2015) as well as through publication in scholarly journals, this research has and will continue to increase the visibility of interdisciplinary work in the fields of cognitive science, second language learning and applied linguistics.

As part of this project, the Co-PIs recruited two undergraduate research assistants from distinct majors (Psychology, Public Health) at UIC to help in all aspects of the project.
